Change of base formula

It is sometimes required to express the logarithm with respect to one base in terms of a logarithm with respect to another base.

Now \(b=a^x\) implies \(\log_a b=x\) where we have used logs to base \(a\). If for some reason we want to use another base, \(p\) say, then we do as follows.

We take logs to base \(p\) of both sides of \(b=a^n\), which gives \(\log_p(b)= \log_p(a^n)=n\log_pa\) (using one of the logarithm laws), so \(n=\dfrac{\log_p(b)}{\log_p(a)}\). But we also have \(\log_ab=n\).

Therefore, we conclude \(\log_ab=\dfrac{\log_p(b)}{\log_p(a)}.\) This is the rule to be used when converting logarithms from one base to another. \[ \log_ab=\dfrac{\log_p(b)}{\log_p(a)}. \] In particular for base \(10\) and natural logs: \[ \log_ab=\dfrac{\log (b)}{\log (a)} \qquad \mbox { and } \qquad \log_ab=\dfrac{\ln (b)}{\ln (a)}. \]


Example

Use the change of base formula to change the base of \(\log_3(7)\) to base \(10\) and base \(e\), thus evaluate this log.

Solution

Using the formula changing to base \(10\) we have, \[ \log_37=\dfrac{\log 7}{\log 3}=\dfrac{0.8450980}{0.4771212}=1.7712437 \] Alternatively, \[ \log_37=\dfrac{\ln 7}{\ln 3}=\dfrac{1.9459101}{1.0986123}=1.7712437 \]
